Would you say that this code compiles or not ? :)

int main()
{
    struct Parent
    {
        void lala();

        protected: int my_var;
    };

    struct Child : Parent
    {
        Child(int my_value)
        {
            my_var = my_value;
        }
    };

    Child foo(2);

    return 0;
}

We don't need to abuse. Yes, struct are C 'structures' but in C++ they are first class citizen in object oriented code. I tend to use them for small things which requires public visibility of their members massively. In fact, I was using class for the forward declaration and struct (same name) for definition and G++ was happy with it but clang failed. The marvellous world of compilers.
